name: adobe brick production | adobe brick | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/27985/documentation

This dataset is a copy of the regional dataset which describes the production of adobe bricks in the area of San Jos√© de Balzay in Ecuador and represents the production of 1 kg of adobe brick. Uncertainty is adjusted accordingly to represent the global situation. 

This dataset starts with the reception of raw materials at the adobe brick production site.

This dataset ends with the storage of the produced adobe brick.This dataset includes the whole manufacturing process to produce adobe bricks (reception of raw materials, dosing, mixing, forming, drying, and storage). The dataset does not include the packaging.
category: C:Manufacturing/23:Manufacture of other non-metallic mineral products/239:Manufacture of non-metallic mineral products n.e.c./2392:Manufacture of clay building materials

processDocumentation.timeDescription: The time period is from 2022 (year of data collection) to 2023 (year of dataset compilation).
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: This dataset represents the production of 1 kg adobe brick at global level. Original data comes from visits to factories in Ecuador. The uncertainty was adjusted accordingly.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Current production technology. This dataset is a copy of the EC geography, and considered representative of the global production of adobe bricks. The manufacturing process includes the reception of raw materials, dosing, mixing, forming, drying, and storage of adobe bricks. The overall process applied in Ecuador implies that a selection of 2 or 3 types of clay is prepared, and mixed with straw and rainwater. The mix is made with the help of the trampling of a horse, then placed in a wooden mold with the shape of a brick (forming process, done by hands). The material in excess on the surface is taken away and reused for the next brick. The mass in the mold is left to dry under the sun. No electricity powered machine nor heat are used during the whole process.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: This dataset is a copy of the EC geography, and considered representative of the global production of adobe bricks. The uncertainty was adjusted accordingly.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: Data gathered in an adobe brick factory through technical visits and process assessment. This dataset is considered representative of the global production of adobe bricks. Uncertainty has been adjusted accordingly.

exchanges.description: The dataset represents 1 kg of an adobe brick, with measured dimensions (23 x 48 x 13) cm (width x length x height) and measured mass of 21,96 kg.

flow.name: adobe brick
flow.category: C:Manufacturing/23:Manufacture of other non-metallic mineral products/239:Manufacture of non-metallic mineral products n.e.c./2392:Manufacture of clay building materials

exchanges.description:
Estimated for infrastructure. Land occupation calculated as the land occupied by the production facility (average 0.024-0.035 ha) divided by the amount of material produced per year at the facility, considering that the adobe brick production in Azuay province is 519000 bricks/year, where there are 5 production areas (see PV comment in EC dataset), and each brick weights on average 21.96 kg.

The ecoinvent data quality guidelines (Section 6.7 Land occupation and transformation, Table 6.1) defins this exchange as follows: "Bare area (non-use): Areas permanently without vegetation (e.g., deserts, high alpine area...)". Such definition is the best fit to the case described in this dataset. Indeed, the factories visited are lcoated on open land areas, usually away from cities, with bare soil on which the producers use the hand-powered machines. There is no complex infrastructure around, in the best case only a simple structure for coverage is made available. The exchanges "Industrial area" and "Urban/industrial fallow (non-use)" are not used, as they would overestimate the impacts, since in the Ecuadorian workshops there are no actual buildings, no asphalted roads, no houses around.

Calculated value. The types of clay used are "fina, cera, cascajo and chagralpa". Total amount of clay used in the beginning of the process is 24.2kg per adobe brick. This would yield roughly 1.12kg of clay/kg of adobe brick. Since casting waste is reused in the mix, the value has been recalculated according to initial shares of clay and straw used in the mix.

exchanges.description: Calculated value. Straw used for the production process based on measurements and the information provided by the owner of the factory. Total amount of straw used in the beginning of the process is 2.372kg per adobe brick. This would yield roughly 0.108kg of straw/kg of adobe brick. Since casting waste is reused in the mix, the value has been recalculated according to initial shares of clay and straw used in the mix.

exchanges.description: Calculated value. Water content used for the production process based on measurements and the information provided by the owner of the factory. Water used for the production of adobe bricks is water obtained from the rain, which is absorbed by the clay.

exchanges.description: Calculated value. Water evaporates while the adobe bricks are drying. Weight of a just made brick and a dry brick are considered.

Calculated value. Straw used for the production process based on measurements and the information provided by the owner of the factory. Total amount of straw used in the beginning of the process is 2.372kg per adobe brick. This would yield roughly 0.108kg of straw/kg of adobe brick. Since casting waste is reused in the mix, the value has been recalculated according to initial shares of clay and straw used in the mix.

exchanges.description: Calculated value. The wastewater was modelled as the water difference between the amount of rainwater used in the process together with the water contained in the clay and straw and the water evaporated to air during the natural drying of the adobe brick. The water is captured in a hole in the ground, where the mixing takes place. Therefore, the excess water is infiltrated by the soil and follows a natural process, where it eventually reaches groundwater or a water body.
